ai-an5:23.5.13_0: and mind that is supreme as “mind that is supreme”;
ai-an5:23.5.14_0: mind immersed in samādhi as “mind immersed in samādhi”,
ai-an5:23.5.15_0: and mind not immersed in samādhi as “mind not immersed in samādhi”;
ai-an5:23.5.18_0: They’re capable of realizing it, in each and every case.
ai-an5:23.6.1_1: ‘May I recollect many kinds of past lives.
ai-an5:23.6.1_2: They recollect many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
ai-an5:23.6.2_0: They’re capable of realizing it, in each and every case.
ai-an5:23.7.1_1: ‘With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, may I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place—and understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds:
ai-an5:23.7.1_2: They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
ai-an5:23.7.2_0: They’re capable of realizing it, in each and every case.
ai-an5:23.8.1_1: ‘May I realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.’
ai-an5:23.8.2_0: They’re capable of realizing it, in each and every case.”
ai-an5:24.1.1_0: “Mendicants, an ethical person, who lacks ethics, has destroyed a vital condition for right immersion.
ai-an5:24.1.2_0: When there is no right immersion, one who lacks right immersion has destroyed a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.
ai-an5:24.1.3_0: When there is no true knowledge and vision, one who lacks true knowledge and vision has destroyed a vital condition for disillusionment and dispassion.
ai-an5:24.1.4_0: When there is no disillusionment and dispassion, one who lacks disillusionment and dispassion has destroyed a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.
ai-an5:24.1.5_0: Suppose there was a tree that lacked branches and foliage.
ai-an5:24.1.6_0: Its shoots, bark, softwood, and heartwood would not grow to fullness.
ai-an5:24.1.7_0: In the same way, an unethical person, who lacks ethics, has destroyed a vital condition for right immersion.
ai-an5:24.1.8_0: When there is no right immersion, one who lacks right immersion has destroyed a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.
ai-an5:24.1.9_0: When there is no true knowledge and vision, one who lacks true knowledge and vision has destroyed a vital condition for disillusionment and dispassion.
ai-an5:24.1.10_0: When there is no disillusionment and dispassion, one who lacks disillusionment and dispassion has destroyed a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.
ai-an5:24.2.1_0: An ethical person, who has fulfilled ethics, has fulfilled a vital condition for right immersion.
ai-an5:24.2.2_0: When there is right immersion, one who has fulfilled right immersion has fulfilled a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.
ai-an5:24.2.3_0: When there is true knowledge and vision, one who has fulfilled true knowledge and vision has fulfilled a vital condition for disillusionment and dispassion.
ai-an5:24.2.4_0: When there is disillusionment and dispassion, one who has fulfilled disillusionment and dispassion has fulfilled a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.
ai-an5:24.2.5_0: Suppose there was a tree that was complete with branches and foliage.
ai-an5:24.2.5_1: Its shoots, bark, softwood, and heartwood would grow to fullness.
ai-an5:24.2.6_0: In the same way, an ethical person, who has fulfilled ethics, has fulfilled a vital condition for right immersion.
ai-an5:24.2.7_0: When there is right immersion, one who has fulfilled right immersion has fulfilled a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.
ai-an5:24.2.8_0: When there is true knowledge and vision, one who has fulfilled true knowledge and vision has fulfilled a vital condition for disillusionment and dispassion.
ai-an5:24.2.9_0: When there is disillusionment and dispassion, one who has fulfilled disillusionment and dispassion has fulfilled a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.”
ai-an5:25.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when right view is supported by five factors it has freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom as its fruit and benefit.
ai-an5:25.2.2_0: It’s when someone has right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion. And they practice properly, they take pleasure in meditation.
ai-an5:25.2.3_0: When right view is supported by these five factors it has freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom as its fruit and benefit.”
ai-an5:26.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five opportunities for freedom. ...
ai-an5:26.2.2_0: Firstly, the Teacher or a respected spiritual companion teaches Dhamma to a mendicant.
ai-an5:26.2.3_0: That mendicant feels inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma, no matter how the Teacher or a respected spiritual companion teaches it.
ai-an5:26.2.4_0: Following the meaning and the teaching, they practice absorption.
ai-an5:26.2.6_0: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.
ai-an5:26.2.7_0: When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss.
ai-an5:26.2.8_0: And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.
ai-an5:26.2.9_0: This is the first opportunity for freedom. ...
ai-an5:26.3.1_0: Furthermore, it may be that neither the Teacher nor a respected spiritual companion teaches Dhamma to a mendicant. But the mendicant teaches Dhamma in detail to others as they learned and memorized it.
ai-an5:26.3.2_0: That mendicant feels inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma, no matter how they teach it in detail to others as they learned and memorized it.
ai-an5:26.3.3_0: Following the meaning and the teaching, they practice absorption.
ai-an5:26.3.5_0: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.
ai-an5:26.3.6_0: When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss.
ai-an5:26.3.7_0: And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.
ai-an5:26.3.8_0: This is the second opportunity for freedom. ...
ai-an5:26.4.1_0: Furthermore, it may be that neither the Teacher nor ... the mendicant teaches Dhamma ... nor does the mendicant recite the teaching.
ai-an5:26.4.2_0: That mendicant feels inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma, no matter how they recite it in detail as they learned and memorized it.
ai-an5:26.4.3_0: Following the meaning and the teaching, they practice absorption.
ai-an5:26.4.5_0: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.
ai-an5:26.4.6_0: When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss.
ai-an5:26.4.7_0: And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.
ai-an5:26.4.8_0: This is the third opportunity for freedom. ...
ai-an5:26.5.1_0: Furthermore, it may be that neither the Teacher nor ... the mendicant teaches Dhamma ... nor does the mendicant recite the teaching.
ai-an5:26.5.2_0: But the mendicant thinks about and considers the teaching in their heart, examining it with the mind as they learned and memorized it.
ai-an5:26.5.3_0: That mendicant feels inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma, no matter how they think about and consider it in their heart, examining it with the mind as they learned and memorized it.
ai-an5:26.5.4_0: Following the meaning and the teaching, they practice absorption.
ai-an5:26.5.6_0: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.
ai-an5:26.5.7_0: When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss.
ai-an5:26.5.8_0: And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.
ai-an5:26.5.9_0: This is the fourth opportunity for freedom. ...
ai-an5:26.6.1_0: Furthermore, it may be that neither the Teacher nor ... the mendicant teaches Dhamma ... nor does the mendicant recite the teaching ... or think about it.
ai-an5:26.6.2_0: But a meditation subject as a foundation of immersion is properly grasped, attended, borne in mind, and comprehended with wisdom.
ai-an5:26.6.3_0: That mendicant feels inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma, no matter how a meditation subject as a foundation of immersion is properly grasped, attended, borne in mind, and comprehended with wisdom.
ai-an5:26.6.4_0: Following the meaning and the teaching, they practice absorption.
ai-an5:26.6.6_0: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.
ai-an5:26.6.7_0: When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss.
ai-an5:26.6.8_0: And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.
ai-an5:26.6.9_0: This is the fifth opportunity for freedom. ...
ai-an5:26.7.1_0: These are the five opportunities for freedom. If a mendicant stays diligent, keen, and resolute at these times, their mind is freed, their defilements are ended, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary.”
ai-an5:26.7.2_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-an5:27.1.1_0: “Mendicants, develop limitless immersion, alert and mindful.
ai-an5:27.1.2_0: When you develop limitless immersion, alert and mindful, five knowledges arise for you personally.
ai-an5:27.1.4_0: The following knowledges arise for you personally: ‘This immersion is blissful now, and results in bliss in the future.’
ai-an5:27.1.6_0: ‘This immersion is not cultivated by sinners.’ ...
ai-an5:27.1.7_0: ‘This immersion is peaceful and sublime and tranquil and unified, not held in place by forceful suppression.’ ...
ai-an5:27.1.8_0: ‘I mindfully enter into and emerge from this world.’
ai-an5:27.2.1_0: Develop the immersion, alert and mindful.
ai-an5:27.2.2_0: When you develop limitless immersion, alert and mindful, these five knowledges arise for you personally.”
ai-an5:28.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you how to develop noble right immersion with five factors.
ai-an5:28.1.2_0: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-an5:28.2.1_0: “Mendicants, what is the noble right immersion with five factors?
ai-an5:28.2.2_0: Firstly, a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption. It has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
ai-an5:28.2.3_0: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
ai-an5:28.2.3_1: so that there is no part of his body unpervaded by the happiness and joy born of seclusion.
ai-an5:28.2.4_0: It’s like when a deft bathroom attendant or their apprentice pours bath powder into a bronze dish, sprinkling it little by little with water.
ai-an5:28.2.4_1: They knead it until the ball of bath powder is soaked and saturated with moisture, spread through inside and out; yet no moisture oozes out.
ai-an5:28.2.5_0: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
ai-an5:28.2.6_0: so that there is no part of his body unpervaded by the happiness and joy born of seclusion.
ai-an5:28.2.7_0: This is the first way to develop noble right immersion with five factors.
ai-an5:28.3.1_0: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption. It has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
ai-an5:28.3.2_0: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
ai-an5:28.3.3_0: so that there is no part of his body unpervaded by the happiness and joy born of concentration.
ai-an5:28.3.4_0: It’s like a deep lake fed by spring water.
ai-an5:28.3.4_1: There’s no inlet to the east, west, north, or south, and no rainfall to replenish it from time to time.
ai-an5:28.3.5_0: But the stream of cool water welling up in the lake drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads throughout the lake.
ai-an5:28.3.5_1: so that there is no part of the lake that is unpervaded by the cool water.
ai-an5:28.3.6_0: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
ai-an5:28.3.7_0: so that there is no part of his body unpervaded by the happiness and joy born of concentration.
ai-an5:28.3.8_0: This is the second way to develop noble right immersion with five factors.
ai-an5:28.4.2_0: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with bliss free of rapture.
ai-an5:28.4.3_0: There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.
ai-an5:28.4.4_0: It’s like a pool with blue water lilies, or pink or white lotuses. Some of them sprout and grow in the water without rising above it, thriving underwater.
ai-an5:28.4.5_0: From the tip to the root they’re drenched, steeped, filled, and soaked with cool water.
ai-an5:28.4.6_0: There’s no part of them that’s not spread through with cool water.
ai-an5:28.4.7_0: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with bliss free of rapture.
ai-an5:28.4.8_0: There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.
ai-an5:28.4.9_0: This is the third way to develop noble right immersion with five factors.
ai-an5:28.5.2_0: They sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind.
ai-an5:28.5.3_0: There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with pure bright mind.
ai-an5:28.5.4_0: It’s like someone sitting wrapped from head to foot with white cloth.
ai-an5:28.5.5_0: so that there is no part of his body uncovered by the white cloth.
ai-an5:28.5.6_0: In the same way, they sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind.
ai-an5:28.5.7_0: There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with pure bright mind.
ai-an5:28.5.8_0: This is the fourth way to develop noble right immersion with five factors.
ai-an5:28.6.1_0: Furthermore, the meditation that is a foundation for reviewing is properly grasped, attended, borne in mind, and comprehended with wisdom by a mendicant.
ai-an5:28.6.2_0: It’s like when someone views someone else. Someone standing might view someone sitting, or someone sitting might view someone lying down.
ai-an5:28.6.3_0: In the same way, the meditation that is a foundation for reviewing is properly grasped, attended, borne in mind, and comprehended with wisdom by a mendicant.
ai-an5:28.6.4_0: This is the fifth way to develop noble right immersion with five factors.
ai-an5:28.7.1_0: When the noble right immersion with five factors is cultivated in this way, a mendicant becomes capable of realizing anything that can be realized by insight to which they extend the mind, in each and every case.
ai-an5:28.8.1_0: Suppose a water jar was placed on a stand, full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.
ai-an5:28.8.2_0: If a strong man was to pour it on any side, would water pour out?”
ai-an5:28.8.4_0: “In the same way, when the noble right immersion with five factors is cultivated in this way, a mendicant becomes capable of realizing anything that can be realized by insight to which they extend the mind, in each and every case.
ai-an5:28.9.1_0: Suppose there was a square, walled lotus pond on level ground, full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.
ai-an5:28.9.2_0: If a strong man was to open the wall on any side, would water pour out?”
ai-an5:28.9.4_0: “In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated these five factors, when developed and cultivated in this way they practice meditation ...”
ai-an5:28.9.4_1: They are capable of realizing it, in each and every case.
ai-an5:28.10.1_0: Suppose a chariot stood harnessed to thoroughbreds at a level crossroads, with a goad ready.
ai-an5:28.10.2_0: Then a deft horse trainer, a master charioteer, might mount the chariot, taking the reins in his right hand and goad in the left. He’d drive out and back wherever he wishes, whenever he wishes.
ai-an5:28.10.3_0: In the same way, when the noble right immersion with five factors is developed and cultivated in this way, a mendicant becomes capable of realizing anything that can be realized by insight to which they extend the mind, and to realization of the fruit of stream-entry.
ai-an5:28.10.4_0: They’re capable of realizing it, in each and every case.
ai-an5:28.11.1_1: ‘May I wield the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying myself and becoming one again ...
ai-an5:28.11.1_2: and may I control the body as far as the Brahmā realm.’
ai-an5:28.11.2_0: They’re capable of realizing it, in each and every case.
ai-an5:28.12.1_1: ‘With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, may I hear both kinds of sounds, human and divine, whether near or far.’
ai-an5:28.12.2_0: They’re capable of realizing it, in each and every case.
ai-an5:28.13.1_0: If they wish: ‘May I understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having comprehended them with my mind,
ai-an5:28.13.2_0: May I understand mind with greed as “mind with greed”,
ai-an5:28.13.3_0: and mind without greed as “mind without greed”;
ai-an5:28.13.18_0: They’re capable of realizing it, in each and every case.
ai-an5:28.14.1_1: ‘May I recollect many kinds of past lives.
ai-an5:28.14.1_2: That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. May I recollect my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.’
ai-an5:28.14.2_0: They’re capable of realizing it, in each and every case.
ai-an5:28.15.1_1: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
ai-an5:28.15.2_0: They’re capable of realizing it, in each and every case.
ai-an5:28.16.1_1: ‘May I realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.’
ai-an5:28.16.2_0: They’re capable of realizing it, in each and every case.”
ai-an5:29.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are five benefits of walking meditation.
ai-an5:29.1.3_0: They’re able to act independent of striving. They practice walking mindfully, and they keep themselves healthy.
ai-an5:29.1.4_0: These are the five benefits of walking meditation.”
ai-an5:30.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins named Icchānaṅgala.
ai-an5:30.1.3_0: He stayed in a forest near Icchānaṅgala.
ai-an5:30.1.4_0: The brahmins and householders of Icchānaṅgala heard:
ai-an5:30.1.5_0: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Icchānaṅgala.
ai-an5:30.1.5_1: is dwelling near Icchānaṅgala in the Icchānaṅgala jungle thicket,
ai-an5:30.1.7_0: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
ai-an5:30.1.8_0: He realizes with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
ai-an5:30.1.9_0: He teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
ai-an5:30.1.10_0: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
ai-an5:30.1.11_0: Then, when the night had passed, they took many different foods and went to the forest near Icchānaṅgala.
ai-an5:30.1.11_1: and after approaching they made a dreadful racket,
ai-an5:30.2.1_0: Now, at that time Venerable Nāgita was the Buddha’s attendant.
ai-an5:30.2.2_0: Then the Buddha said to Nāgita,
ai-an5:30.2.3_0: “Nāgita, who’s making that dreadful racket? You’d think it was fishermen hauling in a catch!”
ai-an5:30.2.4_0: “Sir, it’s these brahmins and householders of Icchānaṅgala. They’ve brought many different foods, and they’re standing outside the gates wanting to offer it specially to the Buddha and the mendicant Saṅgha.”
ai-an5:30.2.5_0: “Nāgita, may I never become famous. May fame not come to me.
ai-an5:30.2.6_0: There are those who can’t get the bliss of renunciation, the bliss of seclusion, the bliss of peace, the bliss of awakening when they want, without trouble or difficulty like I can.
ai-an5:30.2.7_0: Let them enjoy the filthy, lazy pleasure of possessions, honor, and popularity.”
ai-an5:30.3.1_0: “Sir, may the Blessed One please relent now! May the Holy One relent!
ai-an5:30.3.2_0: now, reverend Sir, the Fortunate One’s consent
ai-an5:30.3.3_0: Wherever the Buddha now goes, the brahmins and householders will incline the same way, as will the people of town and country.
ai-an5:30.3.4_0: It’s like when the rain falls heavily.
ai-an5:30.3.5_0: In the same way, wherever the Buddha now goes, the brahmins and householders will incline the same way, as will the people of town and country.
ai-an5:30.3.7_0: Because of the Buddha’s ethics and wisdom.”
ai-an5:30.4.1_0: “Nāgita, may I never become famous. May fame not come to me.
ai-an5:30.4.2_0: There are those who can’t get the bliss of renunciation, the bliss of seclusion, the bliss of peace, the bliss of awakening when they want, without trouble or difficulty like I can.
ai-an5:30.4.3_0: Let them enjoy the filthy, lazy pleasure of possessions, honor, and popularity.
ai-an5:30.4.4_0: What you eat, drink, chew, and taste ends up as excrement and urine.
ai-an5:30.4.6_0: When loved ones decay and perish, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress arise.
ai-an5:30.4.8_0: When they exercise the meditation on ugliness, rejoicing features,
ai-an5:30.4.10_0: When you meditate observing impermanence in the six fields of contact, revulsion at contact becomes stabilized.
ai-an5:30.4.12_0: When you meditate observing rise and fall in the five grasping aggregates, revulsion at grasping becomes stabilized.
ai-an5:30.4.15_0: The third sub-chapter on five factors is finished.
ai-an5:30.5.4_0: and walked back and forth in the same way.
ai-an5:31.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-an5:31.1.2_0: Then Princess Sumanā, escorted by five hundred chariots and five hundred royal maidens, went up to the Buddha.
ai-an5:31.1.2_2: While sat on one side the Prince said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-an5:31.2.1_0: “Sir, suppose there were two disciples equal in faith, ethics, and wisdom.
ai-an5:31.2.2_0: One is a giver, one is not.
ai-an5:31.2.3_0: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
ai-an5:31.2.4_0: When they have become gods, would there be any distinction or difference between them?”
ai-an5:31.3.1_0: “There would be, Sumanā,” said the Buddha.
ai-an5:31.3.2_0: “As a god, the one who was a giver would surpass the other in five respects:
ai-an5:31.3.3_0: divine life span, beauty, happiness, fame, and sovereignty.
ai-an5:31.3.4_0: As a human being, the one who was a giver would surpass the other in these five respects.”
ai-an5:31.4.1_0: “But sir, if they pass away from there and come back to this state of existence as human beings, would there still be any distinction or difference between them?”
ai-an5:31.4.2_0: “There would be, Sumanā,” said the Buddha.
ai-an5:31.4.3_0: “As a human being, the one who was a giver would surpass the other in five respects:
ai-an5:31.4.4_0: human lifespan, beauty, happiness, fame, and sovereignty.
ai-an5:31.4.5_0: As a human being, the one who was a giver would surpass the other in these five respects.”
ai-an5:31.5.1_0: “But sir, if they both go forth from the lay life to homelessness, would there still be any distinction or difference between them?”
ai-an5:31.5.2_0: “There would be, Sumanā,” said the Buddha.
ai-an5:31.5.3_0: “As a renunciate, the one who was a giver would surpass the other in five respects:
ai-an5:31.5.4_0: They’d usually use only what they’ve been invited to accept—robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—rarely using them without invitation.
ai-an5:31.5.5_0: When living with other spiritual practitioners, they usually treat them agreeably by way of body, speech, and mind, rarely disagreeably.
ai-an5:31.5.6_0: As a renunciate, the one who was a giver would surpass the other in these five respects.”
ai-an5:31.6.1_0: “But sir, if they both attain perfection, as perfected ones would there still be any distinction or difference between them?”
ai-an5:31.6.2_0: “In that case, I say that there is no difference between the freedom of one and the freedom of the other.”
ai-an5:31.7.2_0: Just this much is quite enough to justify giving gifts and making merit.
ai-an5:31.7.3_0: For merit is helpful for those who have become gods, human beings, and renunciates.”
ai-an5:31.7.5_0: It’s quite enough to justify giving gifts and making merit.
ai-an5:31.7.6_0: For merit is helpful for those who have become gods, human beings, and renunciates.”
ai-an5:31.8.1_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-an5:31.8.2_0: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
ai-an5:31.9.2_0: journeying across the dimension of space;
ai-an5:31.11.2_0: its hundred peaks wreathed in lightning,
ai-an5:31.12.1_0: Even so, an astute person accomplished in vision,
ai-an5:31.12.2_0: Soṇa, a disciple of the Buddha,
ai-an5:31.13.4_0: they depart to rejoice in heaven.”
ai-an5:32.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-an5:32.1.2_0: Then Princess Cundī, escorted by five hundred chariots and five hundred royal maidens, went up to the Buddha.
ai-an5:32.2.1_0: “Sir, my brother, Prince Cunda, says this:
ai-an5:32.2.2_0: ‘Take a woman or man who goes for refuge to the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, lie, or take alcoholic drinks that cause negligence. Only then do they get reborn in a good place, not a bad place, when their body breaks up, after death.’
ai-an5:32.2.3_0: And so I ask the Buddha:
ai-an5:32.2.4_0: ‘Sir, how do you have confidence in those without it?
ai-an5:32.2.5_0: Sir, what kind of teaching should you have confidence in so as to be reborn in a good place, not a bad place, when the body breaks up, after death?
ai-an5:32.2.6_0: Sir, what kind of Saṅgha should you have confidence in so as to be reborn in a good place, not a bad place, when the body breaks up, after death?
ai-an5:32.3.1_0: “Cundī, the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, is said to be the best of all sentient beings—be they footless, with two feet, four feet, or many feet; with form or formless; with perception or without perception or with neither perception nor non-perception.
ai-an5:32.3.2_0: Those who have confidence in the Buddha have confidence in the best.
ai-an5:32.3.3_0: They have confidence in the best.
ai-an5:32.4.1_0: The noble eightfold path is said to be the best of all conditioned things.
ai-an5:32.4.2_0: Those who have confidence in the noble eightfold path have confidence in the best.
ai-an5:32.5.1_0: The phenomena that are conditioned or unconditioned is said to be the best of all things.
ai-an5:32.5.2_0: That is, the quelling of vanity, the removing of thirst, the uprooting of clinging, the breaking of the round, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.
ai-an5:32.5.3_0: Those who have confidence in the teaching of fading away have confidence in the best.
ai-an5:32.5.4_0: They have confidence in the best.
ai-an5:32.6.1_0: The Saṅgha of the Realized One’s disciples is said to be the best of all communities and groups.
ai-an5:32.6.2_0: It consists of the four pairs, the eight individuals. This is the Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples that is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.
ai-an5:32.6.3_0: Those who have confidence in the Saṅgha have confidence in the best.
ai-an5:32.6.4_0: They have confidence in the best.
ai-an5:32.7.1_0: The ethical conduct loved by the noble ones is said to be the best of all ethics.
ai-an5:32.7.2_0: It is unbroken, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.
ai-an5:32.7.3_0: Those who fulfill the ethics loved by the noble ones fulfill the best.
ai-an5:32.8.1_0: For those who, knowing the best teaching,
ai-an5:32.8.2_0: base their confidence on the best—
ai-an5:32.8.3_0: confident in the best Awakened One,
ai-an5:32.8.4_0: supremely worthy of a religious donation;
ai-an5:32.9.1_0: confident in the best Awakened One,
ai-an5:32.9.2_0: the bliss of fading and stilling;
ai-an5:32.11.1_0: An intelligent person gives to the best,
ai-an5:32.11.3_0: When they become a god or human,
ai-an5:32.11.4_0: they rejoice at reaching the best.”
ai-an5:33.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Bhaddiya in the Jātiyā Grove.
ai-an5:33.1.2_0: Then Uggaha, Meṇḍaka’s grandson, went to the Fortunate One,
ai-an5:33.2.1_0: “Sir, may the Buddha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me, together with three other monks.”
ai-an5:33.2.2_0: The Buddha consented by remaining silent.
ai-an5:33.2.3_0: Knowing that the Buddha had consented, Uggaha got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.
ai-an5:33.3.1_0: Then when the night had passed, the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Uggaha’s home.
ai-an5:33.3.1_1: and after going, he sat down on the prepared seat.
ai-an5:33.3.2_0: Then Uggaha served and satisfied the Buddha with his own hands with a variety of delicious foods.
ai-an5:33.3.3_0: When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, Uggaha sat down to one side,
ai-an5:33.3.5_0: “Sir, these girls of mine will be going to their husbands’ families.
ai-an5:33.3.7_0: and instruct them. It will be for their lasting welfare and happiness.”
ai-an5:33.4.1_0: Then the Buddha said to those girls:
ai-an5:33.4.2_0: “So, girls, you should train like this:
ai-an5:33.4.3_0: ‘Our parents will give us to a husband wanting what’s best, out of kindness and compassion. We will get up before him and go to bed after him, and be obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely.’
ai-an5:33.5.1_0: So, girls, you should train like this:
ai-an5:33.5.2_0: ‘Those our husband respects—mother and father, ascetics and brahmins—we will honor, respect, revere, and venerate, and serve with a seat and a drink when they come as guests.’
ai-an5:33.6.1_0: So, girls, you should train like this:
ai-an5:33.6.2_0: ‘We will be skilled and tireless in doing domestic duties for our husband, such as knitting and sewing. We will have an understanding of how to go about things in order to complete and organize the work.’
ai-an5:33.7.1_0: So, girls, you should train like this:
ai-an5:33.7.2_0: ‘We will know what work our husband’s domestic bondservants, workers, and staff have completed, and what they’ve left incomplete. We will know who is sick, and who is fit or unwell. We will distribute to each a fair portion of various foods.’
ai-an5:33.8.1_0: So, girls, you should train like this:
ai-an5:33.8.2_0: ‘We will ensure that any income our husbands earn is guarded and protected, whether money, grain, silver, or gold. We will not overspend, steal, waste, or lose it.’
ai-an5:33.8.4_0: When they have these five qualities, females—when their body breaks up, after death—are reborn in company with the Gods of the Lovable Host.
ai-an5:33.9.1_0: She’d never look down on her husband,
ai-an5:33.9.2_0: who’s always eager to work hard,
ai-an5:33.10.1_0: And a good woman never scolds her husband
ai-an5:33.11.1_0: She gets up early, works tirelessly,
ai-an5:33.12.1_0: A lady who fulfills these duties
ai-an5:34.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
ai-an5:34.1.2_0: Then General Sīha went to the Buddha.
ai-an5:34.1.3_0: “Sir, can you point out a fruit of giving that’s apparent in the present life?”
ai-an5:34.2.2_0: “A giver, a donor is dear and beloved to many people.
ai-an5:34.2.3_0: This is a fruit of giving that’s apparent in the present life.
ai-an5:34.3.1_0: Furthermore, good people associate with a giver.
ai-an5:34.3.2_0: This is another fruit of giving that’s apparent in the present life.
ai-an5:34.4.1_0: Furthermore, a giver gains a good reputation.
ai-an5:34.4.2_0: This is another fruit of giving that’s apparent in the present life.
ai-an5:34.5.1_0: Furthermore, a giver enters any kind of assembly bold and assured, whether it’s an assembly of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics.
ai-an5:34.5.2_0: This is another fruit of giving that’s apparent in the present life.
ai-an5:34.6.1_0: Furthermore, when his body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
ai-an5:34.6.2_0: This is another fruit of giving that’s conducive to heaven.”
ai-an5:34.7.1_0: When he said this, General Sīha said to the Buddha,
ai-an5:34.7.2_0: “When it comes to those four fruits of giving that are apparent in the present life, I don’t have to rely on faith in the Buddha,
ai-an5:34.7.3_0: I’m a giver, a donor, and am dear and beloved to many people.
ai-an5:34.7.4_0: I’m a giver, and good people associate with me.
ai-an5:34.7.5_2: ‘General Sīha gives, serves, and attends on the Saṅgha.’
ai-an5:34.7.6_0: I’m a giver, and I enter any kind of assembly bold and assured, whether it’s an assembly of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics.
ai-an5:34.7.7_0: When it comes to these four fruits of giving that are apparent in the present life, I don’t have to rely on faith in the Buddha,
ai-an5:34.7.9_0: when their body breaks up, after death, I’m reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
ai-an5:34.7.9_1: For I can go too far from the Buddha.”
ai-an5:34.7.10_0: “That’s so true, Sīha! That’s so true!
ai-an5:34.7.11_0: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
ai-an5:34.8.1_0: One who gives is held dear, many (people) keep company with him,
ai-an5:34.8.2_0: You get a good reputation, and your fame grows.
ai-an5:34.9.1_0: So an astute person, seeking happiness, would give gifts,
ai-an5:34.9.2_0: having driven out the stain of stinginess.
ai-an5:34.9.3_0: They are established for a long time in Heaven,
ai-an5:34.9.4_0: They delight when gone to fellowship with the gods.
ai-an5:34.10.1_0: Having taken the opportunity to do good, when they pass from here
ai-an5:34.10.2_0: they wander radiant in the Garden of Delight.
ai-an5:34.10.3_0: There they delight, rejoice, and enjoy themselves,
ai-an5:34.10.4_0: provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
ai-an5:34.10.5_0: Having practiced the word of the unattached, the poised,
ai-an5:34.10.6_0: (There are) disciples of the Happy One.”
ai-an5:35.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are five benefits of giving.
ai-an5:35.1.3_0: A giver, a donor is dear and beloved by many people.
ai-an5:35.1.4_0: Good people associate with good people.
ai-an5:35.1.6_0: They don’t neglect a layperson’s duties.
ai-an5:35.1.7_0: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
ai-an5:35.1.8_0: These are the five benefits of giving.
ai-an5:35.2.2_0: and follows the way of the good.
ai-an5:35.3.3_0: And understanding this Teaching in this very life,
ai-an5:36.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five timely gifts.
ai-an5:36.1.4_0: A gift one gives to an end,
ai-an5:36.1.5_0: A gift to those who are sick
ai-an5:36.1.6_0: A gift at a time of famine.
ai-an5:36.1.7_0: Presenting the freshly harvested grains and fruits first to those who are ethical.
ai-an5:36.1.8_0: These are the five timely gifts.
ai-an5:36.2.1_0: The wise give at the right time,
ai-an5:36.2.3_0: A religious donation at the right time
ai-an5:36.2.4_0: to the noble ones, upright and poised,
ai-an5:36.3.1_0: given with a clear and confident mind,
ai-an5:36.3.5_0: don’t miss out on the offering;
ai-an5:36.3.6_0: they too have a share in the merit.
ai-an5:36.4.1_0: So you should give without holding back,
ai-an5:36.4.2_0: where a gift is very fruitful.
ai-an5:36.4.3_0: The good deeds of sentient beings
ai-an5:36.4.4_0: support them in the next world.”
ai-an5:36.4.5_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-an5:37.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when a giver gives food, they give the recipients five things.
ai-an5:37.1.3_0: Long life, beauty, happiness, strength, and eloquence.
ai-an5:37.1.4_0: Giving long life, they have long life as a god or human.
ai-an5:37.1.5_0: Giving beauty, they have beauty as a god or human.
ai-an5:37.1.6_0: Giving happiness, she has happiness as a god or human.
ai-an5:37.1.7_0: Giving strength, she has strength as a god or human.
ai-an5:37.1.8_0: Giving gifts, she has given a god or human.
ai-an5:37.1.9_0: When a giver gives food, they give the recipients five things.
ai-an5:37.2.1_0: A wise one is a giver of life, strength,
ai-an5:38.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a faithful gentleman gets five benefits.
ai-an5:38.1.3_0: The good persons in the world show compassion first to the faithful, not so much to the unfaithful.
ai-an5:38.1.4_0: They first approach the faithful, not so much the unfaithful.
ai-an5:38.1.5_0: They first receive alms from the faithful, not so much the unfaithful.
ai-an5:38.1.6_0: They first teach Dhamma to the faithful, not so much the unfaithful.
ai-an5:38.1.7_0: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
ai-an5:38.1.8_0: A faithful gentleman gets these five benefits.
ai-an5:38.2.1_0: Suppose there was a great banyan tree at a level crossroads. It would become a refuge for birds from all around.
ai-an5:38.2.2_0: In the same way, a faithful gentleman becomes a refuge for many people—monks, nuns, laywomen, and laymen.
ai-an5:38.3.1_0: With its branches, leaves, and fruit,
ai-an5:38.3.2_0: a great tree with its strong trunk,
ai-an5:38.4.3_0: Those that need shade go in the shade,
ai-an5:38.4.4_0: those that need fruit enjoy the fruit.
ai-an5:38.5.1_0: So too, when the family head
ai-an5:38.6.1_0: free of greed, free of hate,
ai-an5:38.6.3_0: fields of merit for the world,
ai-an5:38.7.3_0: And understanding this Teaching in this very life,
ai-an5:39.1.1_0: “Mendicants, parents see five reasons to wish for the birth of a child in the family.
ai-an5:39.1.3_0: Since we looked after them, they’ll look after us.
ai-an5:39.1.4_0: They’ll do their duty for us.
ai-an5:39.1.6_0: They’ll take care of the inheritance.
ai-an5:39.1.7_0: Or again they will perhaps those who have died
ai-an5:39.1.8_0: Parents see these five reasons to wish for the birth of a child in the family.
ai-an5:39.2.2_0: astute people wish for a child.
ai-an5:39.2.3_0: Since we looked after them, they’ll look after us.
ai-an5:39.2.4_0: They’ll do their duty for us.
ai-an5:39.3.2_0: They’ll take care of the inheritance.
ai-an5:39.3.3_0: Or else when we have passed away
ai-an5:39.3.4_0: they’ll give an offering on our behalf.
ai-an5:39.4.2_0: astute people wish for a child.
ai-an5:39.5.2_0: remembering what they have done in the past,
ai-an5:39.5.4_0: as their parents did for them in the past.
ai-an5:39.6.1_0: Following their advice, looking after those who raised them,
ai-an5:39.6.2_0: the family traditions are not lost.
ai-an5:39.6.3_0: One who is faithful, accomplished in ethics,
ai-an5:40.1.1_0: “Mendicants, great sal trees grow in five ways supported by the Himalayas, the king of mountains.
ai-an5:40.1.8_0: Great sal trees grow in these five ways supported by the Himalayas, the king of mountains.
ai-an5:40.1.9_0: In the same way, a family grows in five ways supported by a family head with faith.
ai-an5:40.1.16_0: A family grows in these five ways supported by a family head with faith.
ai-an5:40.2.2_0: in the wilds, the formidable forest,
ai-an5:40.2.4_0: to become lord of the forest.
ai-an5:40.3.1_0: So too, when the family head
ai-an5:40.4.1_0: Seeing the ethical conduct of the virtuous,
ai-an5:40.5.2_0: the path that goes to a good place,
ai-an5:40.5.3_0: they delight in the heavenly realm,
ai-an5:40.5.4_0: enjoy all the pleasures they desire.
ai-an5:40.5.6_0: The fourth sub-chapter on well is finished.
ai-an5:41.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-an5:41.1.2_0: Then he went to the Buddha,
ai-an5:41.1.2_2: While sitting on one side the Fortunate One said this to the householder Anāthapiṇḍika:
ai-an5:41.1.3_0: “(There are) these five uses of wealth, householder.
ai-an5:41.1.5_0: To start with, with his legitimate wealth he makes himself happy and pleased, keeping himself properly happy.
ai-an5:41.1.6_0: He makes his mother and father happy ...
ai-an5:41.1.7_0: He makes his children, partners, bondservants, workers, and staff happy ...
ai-an5:41.1.8_0: this is the first use of wealth.
ai-an5:41.2.1_0: Furthermore, with his legitimate wealth he makes his friends and colleagues happy ...
ai-an5:41.2.2_0: This is the second reason to get rich.
ai-an5:41.3.1_0: Furthermore, with his legitimate wealth he protects himself against losses from such things as fire, water, kings, bandits, or unloved heirs.
ai-an5:41.3.2_0: from fire or from water or from kings or from thieves or from unloved heirs,
ai-an5:41.3.4_0: this is the third use of wealth.
ai-an5:41.4.1_0: Furthermore, with his legitimate wealth he makes five spirit-offerings:
ai-an5:41.4.2_0: to relatives, guests, ancestors, king, and deities.
ai-an5:41.4.3_0: This is the fourth reason to get rich.
ai-an5:41.5.1_0: Furthermore, with his legitimate wealth he establishes an uplifting religious donation for ascetics and brahmins—those who avoid intoxication and negligence, are settled in patience and gentleness, and who tame, calm, and extinguish themselves—that’s conducive to heaven, ripens in happiness, and leads to heaven.
ai-an5:41.5.2_0: This is the fifth reason to get rich.
ai-an5:41.5.3_0: These, householder, are the five uses of wealth.
ai-an5:41.6.1_0: But if the riches a noble disciple gets for these five reasons they think:
ai-an5:41.6.2_0: ‘So, the riches I have obtained for these reasons are running out.’
ai-an5:41.6.3_0: And so he has no regrets.
ai-an5:41.6.4_0: But if the riches a noble disciple gets for these five reasons increase, he thinks:
ai-an5:41.6.5_0: ‘So, the riches I have obtained for these reasons are increasing.’
ai-an5:41.6.6_0: And so he has no regrets in both cases.
ai-an5:41.7.1_0: Wealth enjoyed by servants and brothers, or for overcoming misfortunes by me,
ai-an5:41.7.2_0: I am victorious in those water
ai-an5:41.7.5_0: I have served the ethical and
ai-an5:41.8.2_0: for which an astute lay person
ai-an5:41.8.4_0: I don’t regret what I’ve done.’
ai-an5:41.9.1_0: A mortal person who recollects this
ai-an5:41.9.2_0: a standing on the teaching of the noble ones.
ai-an5:41.9.3_0: They praise him in this life,
ai-an5:41.9.4_0: they depart to rejoice in heaven.”
ai-an5:42.1.1_0: “Mendicants, a good person is born in a family for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of the people.
ai-an5:42.1.2_0: For the benefit, welfare, and happiness of mother and father;
ai-an5:42.1.5_0: for the welfare, benefit, and happiness of friends.
ai-an5:42.2.1_0: It’s like a great rain cloud, which nourishes all the crops for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of the people.
ai-an5:42.2.2_0: In the same way, a good person is born in a family for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of the people. ...
ai-an5:42.2.3_0: For the benefit, welfare, and happiness of mother and father;
ai-an5:42.2.6_0: for the welfare, benefit, and happiness of friends.
ai-an5:42.3.1_0: The gods protect one who is guarded by principle,
ai-an5:42.3.2_0: who uses their wealth for the welfare of the many.
ai-an5:42.3.3_0: One who is learned, with precepts and observances intact,
ai-an5:42.3.4_0: and steady in principle, doesn’t lose their reputation.
ai-an5:42.4.1_0: Firm in principle, accomplished in ethical conduct,
ai-an5:42.4.3_0: like a pendant of river gold,
ai-an5:42.4.4_0: who is worthy to criticize them?
ai-an5:42.4.6_0: and by Brahmā, too, they’re praised.”
ai-an5:43.1.1_0: Then he went to the Buddha,
ai-an5:43.1.1_2: While sitting on one side the Fortunate One said this to the householder Anāthapiṇḍika:
ai-an5:43.2.1_0: “Householder, these five things that are likable, desirable, and agreeable are hard to get in the world.
ai-an5:43.2.4_0: likable, desirable, and agreeable things that are rare in the world.
ai-an5:43.2.6_0: Mental, agreeable, pleasing, and rare in the world.
ai-an5:43.2.8_0: These are the five things that are likable, desirable, and agreeable, but hard to get in the world.
ai-an5:43.3.1_0: And I say that these five things are not got by praying or wishing for them.
ai-an5:43.3.2_0: If they were, who would lack them?
ai-an5:43.4.1_0: A noble disciple who wants to be reborn in company with the span of life, or hope for it, or pine for it.
ai-an5:43.4.2_0: Instead, they should practice the way that leads to long life.
ai-an5:43.4.3_0: For by practicing that way they gain long life.
ai-an5:43.4.4_0: as a god or a human being.
ai-an5:43.5.1_0: A noble disciple who wants to be beautiful ought not pray for it, or hope for it, or pine for it.
ai-an5:43.5.2_0: Instead, they should practice the way that leads to beauty.
ai-an5:43.5.3_0: For by practicing that way they gain beauty
ai-an5:43.5.4_0: as a god or a human being.
ai-an5:43.6.1_0: A noble disciple who wants to be happy happily happily or hope for it, or pine for it.
ai-an5:43.6.2_0: Instead, they should practice the way that leads to happiness.
ai-an5:43.6.3_0: For by practicing that way they gain happiness
ai-an5:43.6.4_0: as a god or a human being.
ai-an5:43.7.1_0: A noble disciple who wants to be famous ought not pray for it, or hope for it, or pine for it.
ai-an5:43.7.2_0: Instead, they should practice the way that leads to fame.
ai-an5:43.7.3_0: For by practicing that way they gain fame
ai-an5:43.7.4_0: as a god or a human being.
ai-an5:43.8.1_0: A noble disciple who wants to go to heaven ought not pray for it, or hope for it, or pine for it.
ai-an5:43.8.2_0: Instead, they should practice the way that leads to heaven.
ai-an5:43.8.3_0: For by practicing that way they gain happiness
ai-an5:43.8.4_0: they are one who gains the heavens.
ai-an5:43.9.1_0: For one who desires a continuous flow
ai-an5:43.9.3_0: long life, beauty, fame and reputation,
ai-an5:43.9.4_0: heaven, and birth in an eminent family—
ai-an5:43.11.3_0: That wise one is the teacher
ai-an5:44.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
ai-an5:44.1.2_0: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of the householder Ugga of Vesālī.
ai-an5:44.1.2_1: and after going, he sat down on the prepared seat.
ai-an5:44.1.3_0: Then Ugga went up to Vesālī,
ai-an5:44.2.1_0: “Sir, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
ai-an5:44.2.2_0: ‘The giver of the agreeable gets the agreeable.’
ai-an5:44.2.3_0: My sal flower porridge is agreeable:
ai-an5:44.2.4_0: may the Buddha please accept it from me out of compassion.”
ai-an5:44.2.5_0: So the Buddha accepted them out of compassion.
ai-an5:44.3.1_0: “Sir, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
ai-an5:44.3.2_0: ‘The giver of the agreeable gets the agreeable.’
ai-an5:44.3.3_0: My pork with jujube is agreeable:
ai-an5:44.3.4_0: may the Buddha please accept it from me out of compassion.”
ai-an5:44.3.5_0: So the Buddha accepted them out of compassion.
ai-an5:44.4.1_0: “Sir, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
ai-an5:44.4.2_0: ‘The giver of the agreeable gets the agreeable.’
ai-an5:44.4.3_0: “... My fried vegetable stalks are agreeable:
ai-an5:44.4.4_0: may the Buddha please accept it from me out of compassion.”
ai-an5:44.4.5_0: So the Buddha accepted them out of compassion.
ai-an5:44.5.1_0: “Sir, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
ai-an5:44.5.2_0: ‘The giver of the agreeable gets the agreeable.’
ai-an5:44.5.3_0: “... My boiled fine rice with the dark grains picked out, served with many soups and sauces is agreeable:
ai-an5:44.5.4_0: may the Buddha please accept it from me out of compassion.”
ai-an5:44.5.5_0: So the Buddha accepted them out of compassion.
ai-an5:44.6.1_0: “Sir, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
ai-an5:44.6.2_0: ‘The giver of the agreeable gets the agreeable.’
ai-an5:44.6.3_0: “... My cloths imported from Kāsī are agreeable:
ai-an5:44.6.4_0: May the Buddha please accept them from me out of compassion.”
ai-an5:44.6.5_0: So the Buddha accepted them out of compassion.
ai-an5:44.7.1_0: “Sir, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
ai-an5:44.7.2_0: ‘The giver of the agreeable gets the agreeable.’
ai-an5:44.7.3_0: “... My couch spread with woolen covers—shag-piled or embroidered with flowers—and spread with a fine deer hide, with a canopy above and red pillows at both ends is agreeable.
ai-an5:44.7.5_0: this is not proper for the Buddha.
ai-an5:44.7.6_0: However, this plank of sandalwood is worth over a thousand dollars.
ai-an5:44.7.7_0: may the Buddha please accept it from me out of compassion.”
ai-an5:44.7.8_0: So the Buddha accepted them out of compassion.
ai-an5:44.7.9_0: And then the Buddha rejoiced with Ugga with these verses of appreciation:
ai-an5:44.8.1_0: “The giver of the agreeable gets the agreeable.
ai-an5:44.8.3_0: food and drink, and various requisites
ai-an5:44.9.1_0: Knowing the perfected ones to be like a field
ai-an5:44.9.2_0: for what’s given, offered and not held back,
ai-an5:44.9.3_0: a good person gives what’s hard to give:
ai-an5:44.9.4_0: the giver of the agreeable gets the agreeable.”
ai-an5:44.10.1_0: And then the Buddha approved with this householder Ugga with these verses of appreciation, got up from his seat and left.
ai-an5:44.11.1_0: Then after some time Ugga passed away,
ai-an5:44.11.2_0: When he passed away, Ugga was reborn in a certain host of mind-made body.
ai-an5:44.11.3_0: At that time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-an5:44.11.4_0: Then, late at night, the glorious god Ugga, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha.
ai-an5:44.11.4_1: and after approaching and worshipping the Fortunate One, he stood on one side.
ai-an5:44.11.5_0: “Ugga, I trust it is all you wished?”
ai-an5:44.11.6_0: “Sir, it is indeed just as I wished.”
ai-an5:44.11.7_0: Then the Buddha addressed Ugga with verse:
ai-an5:44.12.1_0: “The giver of the agreeable gets the agreeable.
ai-an5:44.12.2_0: the giver of the foremost gets the foremost,
ai-an5:44.12.3_0: the giver of the excellent gets the excellent,
ai-an5:44.13.1_0: A person who gives the foremost,
ai-an5:44.13.2_0: A person who gives the foremost,
ai-an5:45.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness. They nurture happiness and are conducive to heaven, ripening in happiness and leading to heaven. They lead to what is likable, desirable, agreeable, to welfare and happiness.
ai-an5:45.2.2_0: When a mendicant enters and remains in a limitless immersion of heart while using a robe ...
ai-an5:45.3.1_2: If a monk who uses a bed and chair ...
ai-an5:45.4.1_0: medicines and supplies for the sick, the overflowing of merit for the donor is limitless ...
ai-an5:45.4.2_0: These are the five kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness. They nurture happiness, and are conducive to heaven, ripening in happiness, and leading to heaven. They lead to what is likable, desirable, agreeable, to welfare and happiness.
ai-an5:45.5.1_0: When a noble disciple has these five kinds of overflowing merit and goodness, it’s not easy to grasp how much merit they have by saying that
ai-an5:45.5.2_0: ‘This is how much this overflowing merit ... leads to happiness.’
ai-an5:45.5.3_0: It’s simply reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable, great mass of merit.
ai-an5:45.6.1_0: It’s like trying to grasp how much water is in the ocean. It’s not easy to grasp how much water is in the ocean.
ai-an5:45.6.2_0: ‘This is how many gallons, how many hundreds, thousands, hundreds of thousands of gallons there are.’
ai-an5:45.6.3_0: It’s simply reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable, great mass of water.
ai-an5:45.6.4_0: In the same way, when a noble disciple has these five kinds of overflowing merit and goodness, it’s not easy to grasp how much merit they have:
ai-an5:45.6.5_0: ‘This is how much this overflowing merit ... leads to happiness.’
ai-an5:45.6.6_0: It’s simply reckoned as an incalculable, immeasurable, great mass of merit.
ai-an5:45.7.1_0: Hosts of people use the rivers,
ai-an5:45.7.2_0: and though the rivers are many,
ai-an5:45.7.3_0: all reach the great deep, the boundless ocean,
ai-an5:45.7.4_0: the cruel sea that’s home to precious gems.
ai-an5:45.8.1_0: In the same way, when a person gives food, drink, and clothes;
ai-an5:45.8.2_0: and they’re a giver of beds, seats, and mats—
ai-an5:45.8.3_0: the streams of merit reach that astute person,
ai-an5:45.8.4_0: as the rivers bring their waters to the sea.”
ai-an5:46.1.3_0: Accomplishment in faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
ai-an5:46.1.5_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-an5:47.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these five kinds of wealth.
ai-an5:47.1.3_0: The wealth of faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
ai-an5:47.2.1_0: And what is the wealth of faith?
ai-an5:47.2.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple has faith in the Realized One’s awakening ...
ai-an5:47.2.3_0: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
ai-an5:47.2.4_0: This is called the wealth of faith.
ai-an5:47.3.1_0: And what is the wealth of ethical conduct?
ai-an5:47.3.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, lie, or use alcoholic drinks that cause negligence.
ai-an5:47.3.2_1: refrains from liquors, wines, or intoxicants which cause heedlessness.
ai-an5:47.3.3_0: This is called the wealth of ethical conduct.
ai-an5:47.4.1_0: And what is the wealth of learning?
ai-an5:47.4.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple is very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s totally full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reciting them, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.
ai-an5:47.4.3_0: This is called the wealth of learning.
ai-an5:47.5.1_0: And what is the wealth of generosity?
ai-an5:47.5.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple lives at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.
ai-an5:47.5.3_0: This is called the wealth of generosity.
ai-an5:47.6.1_0: And what is the wealth of wisdom?
ai-an5:47.6.2_0: It’s when a noble disciple is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
ai-an5:47.6.3_0: This is called the wealth of wisdom.
ai-an5:47.6.4_0: These are the five kinds of wealth.
ai-an5:47.7.1_0: Whoever has faith in the Realized One,
ai-an5:47.7.4_0: praised and loved by the noble ones;
ai-an5:47.8.1_0: who has confidence in the Saṅgha,
ai-an5:47.8.3_0: they say that one is poor,
ai-an5:47.8.4_0: their life is not in vain.
ai-an5:47.9.1_0: So let the wise devote themselves
ai-an5:47.9.3_0: confidence, and insight into the teaching,
ai-an5:47.9.4_0: remembering the instructions of the Buddhas.
ai-an5:48.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are five things that cannot be had by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world.
ai-an5:48.1.3_0: That someone liable to old age should not grow old. ...
ai-an5:48.1.4_3: That someone liable to perishing should not perish. ...
ai-an5:48.2.1_0: An uneducated ordinary person liable to grow old.
ai-an5:48.2.2_0: But they don’t reflect on old age:
ai-an5:48.2.3_0: ‘It’s not just me who has someone liable to old age who grows old. For all sentient beings have someone liable to old age who grows old, as long as sentient beings come and go, pass away and are reborn.
ai-an5:48.2.4_0: If I were to sorrow and wail and lament, beating my breast and falling into confusion, just because someone liable to perishing perishes, I’d lose my appetite and my physical appearance would deteriorate. My work wouldn’t get done, my enemies would be encouraged, and my friends would be dispirited.’
ai-an5:48.2.5_0: And so, when someone liable to old age grows old, they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.
ai-an5:48.2.7_0: an uneducated ordinary person struck by sorrow’s poisoned arrow, who only mortifies themselves.
ai-an5:48.3.1_0: Furthermore, an uneducated ordinary person has someone liable to sickness ...
ai-an5:48.3.2_0: But they don’t reflect on perishing:
ai-an5:48.3.3_0: ‘It’s not just me who has someone liable to perishing who perishes. For as long as sentient beings come and go, pass away and are reborn, they all have someone liable to perishing who perishes.
ai-an5:48.3.4_0: If I were to sorrow and wail and lament, beating my breast and falling into confusion, just because someone liable to perishing perishes, I’d lose my appetite and my physical appearance would deteriorate. My work wouldn’t get done, my enemies would be encouraged, and my friends would be dispirited.’
ai-an5:48.3.5_0: And so, when someone liable to perishing perishes, they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.
ai-an5:48.3.7_0: an uneducated ordinary person struck by sorrow’s poisoned arrow, who only mortifies themselves.
ai-an5:48.4.1_0: An educated noble disciple has someone liable to old age who grows old.
ai-an5:48.4.2_0: But they reflect on old age:
ai-an5:48.4.3_0: ‘It’s not just me who has someone liable to old age who grows old. For all sentient beings have someone liable to old age who grows old, as long as sentient beings come and go, pass away and are reborn.
ai-an5:48.4.4_0: If I were to sorrow and wail and lament, beating my breast and falling into confusion, just because someone liable to perishing perishes, I’d lose my appetite and my physical appearance would deteriorate. My work wouldn’t get done, my enemies would be encouraged, and my friends would be dispirited.’
ai-an5:48.4.5_0: And so, when someone liable to old age grows old, they don’t sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.
ai-an5:48.4.7_0: an educated noble disciple who has drawn out sorrow’s poisoned arrow, struck by which uneducated ordinary people only mortify themselves.
ai-an5:48.4.8_0: Sorrowless, free of thorns, that noble disciple only extinguishes themselves.

My work wouldn’t get done, my enemies would be encouraged, and my friends would be dispirited.’
ai-an5:48.5.5_0: And so, when someone liable to perishing perishes, they don’t sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

ai-an5:48.8.1_0: * But when the Wise One does not tremble,
ai-an5:48.8.2_0: as they’re able to assess what’s beneficial,
ai-an5:48.8.4_0: Seeing that his former face is unchanged.
ai-an5:48.9.4_0: (but) from such a person may strike it out.
ai-an5:48.10.1_0: But if you understand that ‘this good thing
ai-an5:48.10.2_0: can’t be had by me or by anyone else’,
ai-an5:48.10.3_0: you should accept it without sorrowing, thinking:
ai-an5:48.10.4_0: I will now do whatever deed is required.”
ai-an5:49.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-an5:49.1.2_0: Then the Kosalan King Pasenadi went to the Fortunate One,
ai-an5:49.2.1_0: Now at that time Queen Mallikā had passed away.
ai-an5:49.2.2_0: Then a certain man went to the Kosalan King Pasenadi,
ai-an5:49.2.2_1: and after approaching he informs the Kosalan King Pasenadi:
ai-an5:49.2.3_0: “Your Majesty, Queen Mallikā has passed away.”
ai-an5:49.2.4_0: When this was said, King Pasenadi was miserable and sad. He sat with his shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.
ai-an5:49.3.1_0: Knowing this, the Buddha said to him,
ai-an5:49.3.2_0: “Great king, there are five things that cannot be had by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world.
ai-an5:49.3.4_0: It’s not possible for someone who old age and death to have someone liable to old age. ...
ai-an5:49.3.4_2: I will now do whatever deed is required.”
ai-an5:50.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Nārada was staying near Pāṭaliputta, in the Chicken Monastery.
ai-an5:50.1.2_0: Now at that time the king’s dear and beloved Queen Bhaddā had passed away.
ai-an5:50.1.3_0: Since then the king does not bathe, anoint himself, eat his meals, or apply himself to his work.
ai-an5:50.1.4_0: Day and night he broods over Queen Bhaddā’s corpse.
ai-an5:50.1.5_0: Then King Piyaka addressed his followers,
ai-an5:50.1.6_0: “So, my good Piyaka, please place Queen Bhaddā’s corpse in an iron case filled with oil. Then close it up with another case, so that we can view Queen Bhaddā’s body even longer.”
ai-an5:50.1.7_0: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied Piyaka the treasurer, and he did as the king instructed.
ai-an5:50.2.2_0: “King Muṇḍa’s dear and beloved Queen Bhaddā has passed away.
ai-an5:50.2.3_0: Since then the king does not bathe, anoint himself, eat his meals, or apply himself to his work.
ai-an5:50.2.4_0: Day and night he broods over Queen Bhaddā’s corpse.
ai-an5:50.2.5_0: Now, what ascetic or brahmin might the king pay homage to, whose teaching could help the king give up sorrow’s arrow?”
ai-an5:50.3.2_0: “This Venerable Nārada is staying in the Chicken Monastery at Pāṭaliputta.
ai-an5:50.3.4_0: ‘He is astute, competent, clever, learned, a brilliant speaker, eloquent, mature, a perfected one.’
ai-an5:50.3.5_0: What if King Muṇḍa was to pay homage to Venerable Nārada? Hopefully when he hears Nārada’s teaching, the king could give up sorrow’s arrow.”
ai-an5:50.4.1_0: Then Piyaka went to the king and said to him,
ai-an5:50.4.2_0: “Sire, this Venerable Nārada is staying in the Chicken Monastery at Pāṭaliputta.
ai-an5:50.4.4_0: ‘He is astute, competent, clever, learned, a brilliant speaker, eloquent, mature, a perfected one.’
ai-an5:50.4.5_0: What if Your Majesty was to pay homage to Venerable Nārada? Hopefully when you hear Nārada’s teaching, you could give up sorrow’s arrow.”
ai-an5:50.4.6_0: “Well then, my good Piyaka, let Nārada know.
ai-an5:50.4.7_0: For how could one such as I presume to visit an ascetic or brahmin in my realm without first letting them know?”
ai-an5:50.4.8_0: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied Piyaka the treasurer.
ai-an5:50.4.8_1: and after approaching and worshipping venerable Nārada, he sat down on one side.
ai-an5:50.4.8_2: He went to Nārada, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
ai-an5:50.5.1_0: “Sir, King Muṇḍa’s dear and beloved Queen Bhaddā has passed away.
ai-an5:50.5.2_0: Since then the king does not bathe, anoint himself, eat his meals, or apply himself to his work.
ai-an5:50.5.3_0: Day and night he broods over Queen Bhaddā’s corpse.
ai-an5:50.5.4_0: Sir, please teach the king so that, when he hears your teaching, he can give up sorrow’s arrow.”
ai-an5:50.5.5_0: “Please, Piyaka, let the king come when he likes.”
ai-an5:50.6.1_0: Then Piyaka got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled Venerable Nārada, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
ai-an5:50.6.1_1: and after approaching he said this to the king:
ai-an5:50.6.2_0: “Sire, the request for an audience with Venerable Nārada has been granted.
ai-an5:50.6.4_0: “Well then, my good Piyaka, harness the finest chariots.”
ai-an5:50.6.5_0: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied Piyaka the treasurer. He did so, then told the king:
ai-an5:50.7.1_0: Then King Muṇḍa mounted a fine carriage and, along with other fine carriages, set out in full royal pomp from Bhaddiya to see Venerable Chief.
ai-an5:50.7.2_0: He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and entered the monastery on foot.
ai-an5:50.7.3_0: Then the king went up to Nārada,
ai-an5:50.7.3_1: and after approaching and worshipping venerable Nārada, he sat down on one side.
ai-an5:50.8.1_0: “Great king, there are five things that cannot be had by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world.
ai-an5:50.8.3_0: That someone liable to old age should not grow old. ...
ai-an5:50.8.4_3: That someone liable to perishing should not perish. ...
ai-an5:50.9.1_0: An uneducated ordinary person liable to old age grows old.
ai-an5:50.9.2_0: But they don’t reflect on old age:
ai-an5:50.9.3_0: ‘It’s not just me who has someone liable to old age who grows old. For all sentient beings have someone liable to old age who grows old, as long as sentient beings come and go, pass away and are reborn.
ai-an5:50.9.4_0: If I were to sorrow and wail and lament, beating my breast and falling into confusion, just because someone liable to perishing perishes, I’d lose my appetite and my physical appearance would deteriorate. My work wouldn’t get done, my enemies would be encouraged, and my friends would be dispirited.’
ai-an5:50.9.5_0: And so, when someone liable to old age grows old, they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.
